tldr: Affected versions of this callback do not support validating a CSRF token by default for the OAuth 2.0 authorization flow. By requiring this as part of the OAuth 2.0 authorization flow, authorization flows are by default secured against cross-site request forgery. This is a breaking change, as it requires the user to pass a CSRF token.
doest_this_affect_me: If you've taken other measues against CSRF during the authorization flow, you may not be affected. Otherwise, you may be affected if you use a vulnerable version.
how_to_fix: Upgrade the library to the patch version, and pass your generated CSRF token via the `handle_callback` function (you also need to provide the CSRF token via the `state` param at the start of the authorization flow).
